questions.text:
1.

(20

pts)

Use

a

standard

(no

variation)

Turing

Machine

that

given

a

string

w

over

{a,b,c}

will

halt

and

accept

strings

of

the

form

a
n
b
2n
c
n
,

n>0.

On

accept,

the

string

should

be

in

its

original

form

with

the

read/write

head

at

the

first

character

of

the

string.

On

reject,

there

is

no

constraint

on

the

state

of

the

string

or

the

location

of

the

read/write

head.

Turn

in

your

pseudocode
,

image

of

your

state

machine

drawn

on

JFLAP ,

and

the

.jff

file

for

your

machine.

criteria: Correct TM design that recognizes { a^n b^{2n} c^n | n > 0 }
Pseudocode clearly explaining states and transitions
JFLAP state diagram image provided and legible
.jff file submitted and loads in JFLAP (if applicable)
On accept: tape content unchanged and head positioned at first character
rubric.instructions: Award full credit for a correct standard (single-tape, no-variation) TM that accepts exactly the described language, leaves the tape in the original string, and places the head at the first character on accept. Mostly correct (95%) for minor issues (e.g., small off-by-one in head movement that is easily fixable) but correct construction and explanation; attempted (50%) if partial strategy shown (e.g., marking scheme or counting idea) but incomplete or incorrect state transition coverage; 0 for no submission.

questions.text:
2.

(20

pts)

Using

any

variation

discussed

in

class

(stay-put,

multi-tape,

multi-head,

multi-track,

nondeterministic,

or

any

combination

of

variations)

design

a

Turing

Machine

that

will

perform

unary

multiplication.

Given

a

string

of

the

form

“#1
n
x1
m
=”,

where

m

and

n
>

0,

halt

and

accept

with

the

read/write

head

on

the

beginning

#

and

a

string

of

this

form

on

the

tape:

“#1
n
x1
m
=1
nxm
#”.


For

example,

given

the

string

“#11x111=”

halt

and

accept

with

the

string

“#11x111=111111#”


(You

may

find

it

helpful

to

look

at

the

examples

of

unary

addition

in

the

lectures.)

Turn

in

your

pseudocode
,

state

machine

image

(drawn

in

JFLAP),

and

.jff

file

(even

if

it

cannot

be

simulated

in

JFLAP).

Be

sure

to

declare

what

type

of

machine

you

are

using

(e.g.

Stay-put

Multi-head

machine

with

3

read/write

heads)

criteria: Correct design demonstrating unary multiplication (produces m*n ones) on the tape as specified
Pseudocode clearly describes the algorithm and tape/head operations
JFLAP diagram image provided and corresponds to pseudocode
.jff file submitted (even if not fully simulatable) for the declared machine type
Declared machine variation/type (stay-put, multi-tape, multi-head, etc.)
Final tape format matches specified form and head positioned at the beginning # on accept
rubric.instructions: Full credit for a correct TM (using any allowed variation) that reliably computes unary multiplication and produces the exact final tape and head position. Mostly correct (95%) for correct overall approach with small implementation flaws or missing corner-case handling. Attempted (50%) for a clear partial solution (e.g., marking and copying strategy begun but incomplete transitions or missing mechanics). Deduct for missing declared machine type or missing required artifacts (.jff, pseudocode, JFLAP image).

questions.text:
3.

(20

pts)

EXTRA

CREDIT :

Design

a

Turing

Machine

using

any

of

the

variations

we

discussed

that

will

simulate

a

string

through

a

DFA.

To

limit

the

scope

of

the

machine,

assume

strings

will

be

given

with

valid

encodings;

the

states

of

the

DFA

will

be

a

subset

of

{0,1,2};

the

alphabet

of

the

DFA

will

be

a

subset

of

{a,b,c}.



The

encoding

will

be

as

follows:

#Sigma#Q#q0#F#

…

transitions

…

##string



Where

the

transitions

are

of

the

form

#fromState

Char

toState#

(with

no

spaces

between

them).


For

example,

to

simulate

running

the

string

“aaaa”

through

the

machine

with

this

5-tuple:

Sigma

=

{a}

Q

=

{0,1}

q0

=

0

F

=

{0}



delta

a

0

1

1

0


The

TM's

input

string

would

be


#a#01#0#0#0a1#1a0##aaaaa


Turn

in

your

pseudocode
,

state

machine

image

(drawn

in

JFLAP),

and

.jff

file

(even

if

it

cannot

be

simulated

in

JFLAP).

Be

sure

to

declare

what

type

of

machine

you

are

using

(e.g.

Stay-put

Multi-head

machine

with

3

read/write

heads)

criteria: Correct parsing of the DFA encoding and the input string
TM correctly simulates the DFA transitions and accepts/rejects accordingly
Pseudocode explains how the TM decodes the encoding and performs simulation
JFLAP diagram image provided and corresponds to the pseudocode
.jff file submitted and declared machine type specified
Handles the specified limits (states subset of {0,1,2} and alphabet subset of {a,b,c})
rubric.instructions: This is extra credit; award full extra points for a correct TM that decodes the encoding and simulates the DFA on the input string. Mostly correct (95%) if decoding or simulation is essentially correct but has minor issues; attempted (50%) for an outlined approach or partial decoding/simulation. Ensure the student declares machine variation and submits pseudocode/JFLAP/.jff artifacts; deduct points for missing artifacts or incorrect handling of the encoding format.

grading_instructions: Grade each question by verifying required deliverables (pseudocode, JFLAP state diagram image, and .jff file) and the correctness of the TM design relative to the specification. For each problem, check: (1) that the machine recognizes/produces the correct language or computation, (2) tape contents and head position on accept when required, (3) declared machine variation (when asked), and (4) clear explanation/pseudocode describing transitions and strategy. Use the per-question rubric: no_submission = 0, attempted = 50% of points, mostly_correct = 95% of points (minor errors), correct = 100% of points. Allocate partial credit for correct core ideas (marking schemes, copying strategies, head movement logic) even if some transitions are missing; deduct for missing artifacts or unclear explanations. Treat question 3 as extra credit (do not include its points in the standard total_points tally).
